AvProblem.comment: Small ridgeline steep terrain and wind-loaded gullies, bowls
<2600 m: glide-snow avalanches on steep smooth slopes and rock plates, forest clearances; moist loose-snow slides due to warmth

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Small drifts at high altitudes. Glide-snow avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanche danger generally is low. Latent danger of glide-snow avalanches persists at high altitudes on steep grass-covered slopes, rock plates and in forest clearances in all aspects, triggerable up to 2600 m on sunny slopes, releases can be medium-sized, more seldom on shady slopes, avoid zones below glide cracks. Wet small loose-snow avalanches can trigger naturally on very steep sunny rough and rocky slopes during the daytime hours. Due to strong NW winds, trigger-prone snowdrift accumulations were generated near ridges, in gullies and bowls. Caution: acute danger of falling. Beware cornices on ridges.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Daytime warming alternates with nocturnal cooling, which settles and stabilizes the snowpack. Solar radiation and higher temperatures make the snowpack wet, forfeit its firmness. Warm ground up to high altitudes makes the base moist-to-wet, reinforcing the gliding movement of the entire snowpack. The strong NW winds generated small snowdrifts. At very high altitudes there are weak layers in the uppermost part of the snowpack, seldom triggerable.
BulletinMeasurements.wxSynopsisComment: Nocturnal hours: Scattered clouds. Tuesday daytime: dry air masses, mild, pleasant conditions with thin cirrus clouds. Winds slackening off. At 2000 m: +4 degrees. Brisk westerly winds.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: On Wednesday, mostly quite sunny, with the selfsame cirrus cloudbanks. The danger of dry-snow avalanches will not change, the gliding snow problem will persist.
